title: Difference between 'Each' and 'Every'
explanation: Always followed by a singular verb. 'Each' is for two or more items (individualistic), 'Every' is for more than two (collective). 'Each' can be a pronoun or adjective; 'Every' is only an adjective.

examples.sentence: Each of the students is responsible.
Every student was given a prize.
Each of the students are responsible.

title: 'Both' and 'not' cannot be used together
explanation: Instead of 'Both...not', use 'Neither...nor'. Example: 'Neither Ram nor Shyam is going' is correct.

examples.sentence: Neither of them is ready for the test.
Both of them are not ready for the test.

title: Usage of Relative Pronouns (who, whom, which, that)
explanation: 'Who'/'Whom' for people. 'Which' for animals/things. 'That' for all, and required after words like 'all', 'any', 'the only', 'the same', and superlatives.

examples.sentence: This is the best book that I have ever read.
This is the best book which I have ever read.

title: Three Types of Conditional Sentences
explanation: Type 1 (Possible): If [Simple Present], [will-future]. Type 2 (Theory): If [Simple Past], [would + V1]. Type 3 (Impossible): If [Past Perfect], [would + have + V3].

examples.sentence: If I were a bird, I would fly to you.
If I was a bird, I would fly to you.

title: Usage of 'One of the'
explanation: 'One of the' + PLURAL NOUN. Use a singular verb ('One of the birds *is* red') unless a relative pronoun is used ('one of the birds *that fly*'). 'The only one of the...' always takes a singular verb.

examples.sentence: He is one of the tallest boys in the class.
He is one of the tallest boy in the class.

quiz.question: ______ of the players has a unique talent.
One of my best ________ is coming to visit me today.
Which sentence is grammatically correct?
options: Both of them are not going.
Both of them is not going.

quiz.question: She is the most intelligent girl ________ I have ever met.
If I ______ you, I would accept the offer.
_______ employee received a bonus.
One of the reasons for his failure ________ his laziness.
The correct alternative for 'Both Ram and Shyam are not honest' is:
options: Neither Ram nor Shyam are honest.
Either Ram or Shyam is honest.
Neither Ram nor Shyam is honest.
quiz.correct_answer: Neither Ram nor Shyam is honest.

quiz.question: This is the house ________ my grandfather built.
What would you do if you ________ a million dollars?

title: 'Number + Unit + Noun' Rule
explanation: The unit is singular when used as an adjective before a noun (e.g., 'a ten-inch snake', 'a five-hundred-rupee note').

examples.sentence: It is a ten-mile walk.
It is a ten-miles walk.

title: Expressions of Time, Money, Distance, etc.
explanation: Takes a singular verb if the amount is treated as a single unit ('Ten miles *is* a long walk'). Takes a plural verb if treated as separate units ('Ten miles *were* covered by car and on foot').

examples.sentence: Five thousand rupees is a good amount.
Five thousand rupees are a good amount.

title: Comparisons within a Group
explanation: When comparing one item to its entire group, use 'any other' to exclude it from the group (e.g., 'Gold is more precious than *any other* metal').

examples.sentence: Ganga is longer than any other river in India.
Ganga is longer than any river in India.

title: Prepositions of Time: 'Since' and 'For'
explanation: 'For' is used for a duration/period of time. 'Since' is used for a specific point in time (the start point).

examples.sentence: It has been raining since morning.
It has been raining for morning.

title: Two Actions in the Past
explanation: The action that happened earlier uses the Past Perfect Tense (had + V3). The action that happened later uses the Simple Past Tense (V2).

examples.sentence: When I reached the station, the train had already departed.
When I reached the station, the train has already departed.

quiz.question: Which sentence is correct?
Fifty kilometers ________ a long distance to travel on foot.
Mumbai is larger than ________ city in India.
She has been living in this house ________ ten years.
The patient ________ before the doctor arrived.
Which of the following is correct?
A thousand dollars ________ a lot of money for me.
No other boy in the class is as tall as ________.
I have been waiting for you ________ 9 AM.
When she ________ the room, he was watching TV.

title: Possessive Adjective before a Gerund
explanation: Use a possessive adjective (my, our, his, her, their) before a gerund (-ing form used as a noun). Example: 'I hope you don't mind *my* borrowing your car.'

examples.sentence: She insisted on my staying for dinner.
She insisted on me staying for dinner.

title: Law of Inversion
explanation: Reversing the normal order (verb before subject), usually for emphasis when a sentence starts with a negative adverb (e.g., 'Never *have I* seen...').

examples.sentence: No sooner did I enter the class than the bell rang.
No sooner I entered the class than the bell rang.

title: Article 'The' with Places
explanation: Do not use 'The' when visiting a place (school, church, hospital) for its primary purpose. Use 'The' when visiting for any other secondary purpose.

examples.sentence: I went to the school to meet my son's teacher.
I went to school to meet my son's teacher.

title: Inversion with 'No sooner', 'Hardly', 'Scarcely'
explanation: When these start a sentence, they must be followed by a helping verb (inversion). The correct pairs are 'No sooner...than' and 'Hardly/Scarcely...when'.

examples.sentence: Hardly had I seen him when I stopped my car.
Hardly I had seen him when I stopped my car.

title: Reflexive Pronouns as Objects
explanation: Verbs like 'enjoy', 'avail', 'absent', 'pride', 'acquit', 'adjust' must be followed by an object. If no other object is present, use a reflexive pronoun (e.g., 'He enjoyed *himself*...').

examples.sentence: He enjoyed himself at the party.
He enjoyed at the party.

title: Verbs Not Followed by Reflexive Pronouns
explanation: Verbs like 'hide', 'keep', 'stop', 'turn', 'bathe' do not take a reflexive pronoun. (e.g., 'He hid in the room,' not 'He hid himself...').

examples.sentence: He hid in the room.
He hid himself in the room.

title: Subject-Verb Agreement with 'as well as', 'along with'
explanation: When two subjects are connected by phrases like 'as well as', 'together with', 'along with', the verb agrees with the *first* subject.

examples.sentence: Ram, as well as his friends, is coming.
Ram, as well as his friends, are coming.

title: Noun vs. Verb Forms
explanation: Be aware of different spellings for nouns and verbs. Nouns: 'Advice', 'Practice', 'Belief'. Verbs: 'Advise', 'Practise', 'Believe'.

examples.sentence: He gave me a piece of advice.
He gave me a piece of advise.

title: Pronoun Case in Comparisons
explanation: Comparisons must be between the same case. (e.g., 'She is taller than *I*.' [Subject to subject] vs. 'My parents scold me more than *him*.' [Object to object]).

examples.sentence: She is taller than I.
She is taller than me.

title: 'Who' vs. 'Whom'
explanation: 'Who' is subjective (replaces with He/She). 'Whom' is objective (replaces with Him/Her). Use the substitution method to check.

examples.sentence: Whom did you see at the cinema?
Who did you see at the cinema?

title: Words Not Taking Possessive Case
explanation: Words like 'separation', 'excuse', 'mention', 'favour', 'pardon' do not take a possessive adjective before them. (e.g., 'Separation *from you*,' not '*Your separation*').

examples.sentence: I need a favor from you.
I need your favor.

title: 'Each other' vs. 'One another'
explanation: 'Each other' is generally used for two people. 'One another' is used for more than two people.

examples.sentence: The two brothers loved each other.
The two brothers loved one another.

title: 'Seldom or never' / 'Little or nothing'
explanation: The correct phrases are 'Seldom or never' or 'Seldom, if ever'. 'Seldom or ever' is incorrect. This also applies to 'Little or nothing' / 'Little, if anything'.

examples.sentence: He seldom or never goes to the movies.
He seldom or ever goes to the movies.

title: 'Very' and 'Much' with Superlatives
explanation: The order is 'the *very* best'. 'Very' modifies positive degree adjectives; 'Much' modifies comparative degrees.

examples.sentence: This is the very best book on the subject.
This is the much best book on the subject.

title: Position of 'Enough'
explanation: As an adjective, it comes *before* the noun ('enough sugar'). As an adverb, it comes *after* the adjective ('smart enough').

examples.sentence: He is smart enough to solve this problem.
He is enough smart to solve this problem.

title: Adverb 'as' with Verbs
explanation: 'as' is used with verbs like 'regard', 'define', 'describe'. 'as' is *not* used with 'elect', 'think', 'consider', 'call', 'appoint'.

examples.sentence: I regard him as my brother.
I regard him my brother.

title: Conjunction 'Although'
explanation: 'Although' (or 'Though') can be followed by 'yet' or nothing. It is *never* followed by 'but'.

examples.sentence: Although he is rich, yet he is unhappy.
Although he is rich, but he is unhappy.

title: Stative Verbs (No '-ing' Form)
explanation: Verbs of possession, perception, or feeling (like 'own', 'see', 'love', 'know', 'taste', 'want') are generally not used in the continuous (-ing) form.

examples.sentence: I am seeing a bird on the tree.
I see a bird on the tree.

title: Words used with Perfect Tense
explanation: Words like 'ever', 'never', 'yet', 'already', 'just now', 'lately', 'recently', 'so far' often signal the use of a Perfect Tense (e.g., 'He *has gone* just now').

examples.sentence: He has gone to Delhi just now.
He went to Delhi just now.

title: Subject-Verb Agreement with Collective Nouns
explanation: Singular verb if the group acts as one unit ('The jury *is*...'). Plural verb if the members act individually ('The jury *are* divided...').

examples.sentence: The jury is unanimous in its verdict.
The jury are unanimous in its verdict.

title: Words Followed by 'to'
explanation: Adjectives ending in '-ior' (Superior, Inferior, Junior, Senior) and words like 'Prefer', 'Known', 'Addicted' are followed by the preposition 'to', not 'than'.

examples.sentence: He is senior to me.
He is senior than me.

title: 'as... as' vs. 'so... as'
explanation: Use 'as... as' for both positive and negative comparisons. Use 'so... as' *only* for negative comparisons. (e.g., 'He is not *so* good as...').

examples.sentence: He is as tall as his brother.
He is so tall as his brother.

title: Comparisons with 'times'
explanation: When using 'times' for comparison, use the 'as... as' structure, not a comparative degree. (e.g., 'three times *as large as*', not 'three times larger than').

examples.sentence: My house is three times as big as yours.
My house is three times bigger than yours.

title: Narration (Indirect Speech)
explanation: Indirect speech is always a statement (Subject + Verb), never a question. (e.g., 'He asked me *where I was* going,' not '...where was I going').

examples.sentence: He asked me where I was going.
He asked me where was I going.

title: Agreement with 'or', 'nor', 'either/or'
explanation: With 'either/or', 'neither/nor', or 'not only/but also', the verb agrees with the *nearest* subject.

examples.sentence: Neither Ram nor his friends are coming.
Neither Ram nor his friends is coming.

title: Comparing Two Qualities of One Object
explanation: Use 'more' + positive form, not a comparative form. (e.g., 'He is *more wise than* intelligent,' not 'He is wiser than intelligent').

examples.sentence: He is more wise than intelligent.
He is wiser than intelligent.

title: 'More than one' and 'Many a'
explanation: 'More than one' and 'Many a' are followed by a singular noun and singular verb. 'Many', 'A good many', 'A great many' take plural nouns and plural verbs.

examples.sentence: More than one student was absent.
More than one students were absent.

title: Connectors with 'Doubt'
explanation: Use 'if' or 'whether' with 'doubt'/'doubtful' in affirmative sentences. Use 'that' with 'no doubt'/'not doubtful' or in negative sentences.

examples.sentence: I doubt if he will come.
I doubt that he will come.

title: Narration: Exceptions to Tense Change
explanation: The tense of reported speech does *not* change if it is a Universal Truth, Historical Fact, Proverb, or Habitual Fact.

examples.sentence: The teacher said that the earth moves around the sun.
The teacher said that the earth moved around the sun.

title: 'little, a little, the little' & 'few, a few, the few'
explanation: `little/few` (hardly any, negative). `a little/a few` (some, positive). `the little/the few` (all that is available). `little` is for uncountable, `few` is for countable.

examples.sentence: He has little money.
He has a little money.

title: Objective Case after Prepositions
explanation: A preposition (like 'but', 'except', 'between') or a verb like 'Let' must be followed by an objective pronoun (me, him, her, us, them).

examples.sentence: Let you and me go.
Let you and I go.

title: Sequence of Personal Pronouns
explanation: For a positive sense, use the 231 order ('You, he and I'). For a negative sense (confession, guilt), use the 123 order ('I, you and he'). If all are plural, use 123 ('We, you and they').

examples.sentence: You, he and I are partners.
I, you and he are partners.

title: Superfluous Errors (Redundancy)
explanation: Avoid redundant words. e.g., 'retreat back', 'suppose if', 'reborn again', 'mutual agreement', 'coward man', 'previous records'.

examples.sentence: Suppose he comes, what will you do?
Suppose if he comes, what will you do?

title: Apostrophe ('s) with Non-Living Things
explanation: Do not use ('s) with non-living things ('legs of the table,' not 'table's legs'). Exceptions: time, weight, distance, personification ('one week's vacation').

examples.sentence: The legs of the table are broken.
The table's legs are broken.

title: Simple Past vs. Present Perfect
explanation: When a specific past time is mentioned ('yesterday', 'last week', '10 days ago'), always use Simple Past Tense (V2), not Present Perfect (have + V3).

examples.sentence: I saw him yesterday.
I have seen him yesterday.

title: Absolute Adjectives
explanation: Adjectives like 'unique', 'excellent', 'perfect', 'ideal', 'complete', 'entire' are non-gradable and are not used with 'most' or in comparative forms.

examples.sentence: This is a unique book.
This is a most unique book.

title: 'Quite' and 'all' not used together
explanation: The words 'quite' and 'all' are never used together. ('He is quite well' or 'He is all right,' not 'He is quite all right').

examples.sentence: He is quite well.
He is quite all right.

title: 'Ago' vs. 'Before'
explanation: Use Simple Past Tense with 'ago'. Use Past Perfect Tense with 'before' (in the context of two past actions).

examples.sentence: He came two days ago.
He had come two days ago.

title: Possessive Sign (Common vs. Split)
explanation: Common Possession (one item): Apostrophe on the last noun only ('Ram and Shyam's car'). Split Possession (separate items): Apostrophe on each noun ('Ram's and Shyam's cars').

examples.sentence: Ram and Shyam's car is new.
Ram's and Shyam's car is new.

title: 'It's' vs. 'Its'
explanation: 'It's' is a contraction for 'It is' or 'It has'. 'Its' is the possessive pronoun (showing ownership).

examples.sentence: It's a beautiful day.
Its a beautiful day.

title: 'A number of' vs. 'The number of'
explanation: 'A number of' + Plural Noun + PLURAL Verb. 'The number of' + Plural Noun + SINGULAR Verb.

examples.sentence: A number of students are absent today.
A number of students is absent today.

title: Phrases 'It is time' / 'It is high time'
explanation: Two correct structures: 1) 'It is time *to work*' (to + V1). 2) 'It is time *he worked*' (Subject + V2). Both refer to the present moment.

examples.sentence: It is time to go home.
It is time for go home.

title: Preposition with 'Angry'
explanation: 'Angry *with* a person'. 'Angry *at* a thing or situation'. The same rule applies to 'Annoy'.

examples.sentence: He is angry with me.
He is angry at me.

title: Verb 'Know' with Infinitives
explanation: The verb 'know' is not followed directly by 'to + V1'. It needs a question word in between. (e.g., 'I know *how to* make tea,' not 'I know to make tea').

examples.sentence: I know how to swim.
I know to swim.

title: Conjunctions 'else', 'other', 'rather'
explanation: 'else' is followed by 'but'. 'other' and 'rather' are followed by 'than'.

examples.sentence: I would rather die than beg.
I would rather die but beg.

title: 'Sort', 'Type', 'Kind'
explanation: These singular words are followed by a singular noun and singular verb. (e.g., 'This *type* of article *is* sold...').

examples.sentence: This type of book is very expensive.
This type of books are very expensive.

title: Prepositions 'in', 'Inside', and 'into'
explanation: 'in' (static position, already inside). 'into' (movement from outside to inside; or change of state). 'inside' (refers to the inner part, often replaceable with 'in').

examples.sentence: He jumped into the river.
He jumped in the river.

title: Prepositions 'with' and 'by'
explanation: 'with' is used for non-living instruments ('write *with* a pen'). 'by' is used for the living agent ('driven *by* a man'). Exception: 'What is the time *by* your watch?'

examples.sentence: He was killed by a robber with a knife.
He was killed with a robber by a knife.

title: Preposition with 'Start'
explanation: Do not use 'from' with 'start' for a single event. (e.g., 'My exams start *on* Monday,' not '...from Monday'). 'From' implies continuation.

examples.sentence: The examination will start on Monday.
The examination will start from Monday.

title: Phrases Followed by Gerund ('To + V1+ing')
explanation: Phrases where 'to' is a preposition, not an infinitive, must be followed by a gerund (-ing). e.g., 'be used to', 'accustomed to', 'addicted to', 'with a view to', 'look forward to'.

examples.sentence: I am looking forward to meeting you.
I am looking forward to meet you.

title: Article 'a' vs. 'an'
explanation: The choice is determined by *sound*, not the letter. 'a' before consonant sounds ('a university', 'a one-rupee note'). 'an' before vowel sounds ('an hour', 'an M.Tech.').

examples.sentence: He is an honest man.
He is a honest man.

title: Usage of Definite Article 'The'
explanation: Use 'The' with: mountain ranges (The Himalayas), rivers, oceans, deserts, religious books, musical instruments, and unique things (The Sun). Also in 'The higher you go, the cooler it is' and 'the better of the two'.

examples.sentence: The Ganga is a holy river.
Ganga is a holy river.

title: Omission of Article 'The'
explanation: Do *not* use 'The' with: names of cities, non-abbreviated countries, continents, streets, single lakes, and single mountain peaks (Mount Everest).

examples.sentence: I live in Delhi.
I live in the Delhi.

title: 'The' + Adjective
explanation: 'The' + Adjective represents the entire group as a plural noun. (e.g., 'The poor' = poor people, 'The honest' = honest people, 'The rich' = rich people).

examples.sentence: The rich are not always happy.
The rich is not always happy.

title: Noun + Preposition + Same Noun
explanation: When a preposition connects two identical nouns, both nouns must be in singular form. (e.g., 'Village after village', 'Book after book', 'Row upon row').

examples.sentence: Ship after ship is arriving.
Ships after ships are arriving.

title: Plurals of Compound Nouns
explanation: Pluralize the main word. (e.g., 'Daughter-in-law' -> 'Daughters-in-law', 'Commander-in-chief' -> 'Commanders-in-chief', 'Passer-by' -> 'Passers-by').

examples.sentence: He has three daughters-in-law.
He has three daughter-in-laws.

title: 'Male'/'Female' vs. 'Man'/'Woman'
explanation: 'Male'/'Female' describes characteristics or type ('female watch'). 'Man'/'Woman' describes the person's gender ('woman doctor' = a doctor who is a woman).

examples.sentence: She is a woman doctor.
She is a female doctor.

title: Antecedent Rule
explanation: The antecedent is the noun/pronoun just before a relative pronoun. If there is no antecedent, use 'whoever' or 'whomever'.

examples.sentence: I know the boy who came here.
I know who came here.

title: Question Tags
explanation: A positive statement has a negative tag, and a negative statement has a positive tag.

examples.sentence: He is a good boy, isn't he?
He is a good boy, is he?

title: Question Tag for 'I am'
explanation: The negative question tag for 'I am' is 'aren't I?', not 'amn't I?' or 'ain't I?'.

examples.sentence: I am right, aren't I?
I am right, am't I?

title: Question Tags with Negative Adverbs
explanation: Words like 'Seldom', 'barely', 'hardly', 'scarcely', 'never' are negative. They must be followed by a *positive* question tag.

examples.sentence: He hardly comes here, does he?
He hardly comes here, doesn't he?

title: Tense in Question Tags
explanation: The helping verb in the question tag must be in the same tense as the main statement.

examples.sentence: He went to school, didn't he?
He went to school, doesn't he?

title: Question Tags for 'Each' & 'Every'
explanation: 'Each/Every' takes a singular verb, but is referred to by a *plural* pronoun ('they') in the question tag. (e.g., 'Every girl *is* talented, *aren't they*?').

examples.sentence: Everyone has come, haven't they?
Everyone has come, hasn't he?

title: Question Tags for Collective Nouns
explanation: If the collective noun is singular (acting as a unit), the tag uses 'it'. If it is plural (acting as individuals), the tag uses 'they'.

examples.sentence: The team has won the match, hasn't it?
The team has won the match, haven't they?

title: Question Tags for Proposals
explanation: For proposals starting with 'Let us...', the question tag is always 'shall we?'.

examples.sentence: Let us go for a walk, shall we?
Let us go for a walk, will we?

title: Prepositions of Time & Place: 'in, on, at'
explanation: Use 'at' for specific points (at 4pm, at the corner). Use 'on' for surfaces or days (on the table, on Sunday). Use 'in' for enclosed areas or months/years (in the box, in April, in 1990).

examples.sentence: He lives at Rohini in Delhi.
He lives in Rohini at Delhi.

title: Conjunction 'Both'
explanation: 'Both' is always followed by 'and'. It is *never* followed by 'as well as'.

examples.sentence: He is both intelligent and hardworking.
He is both intelligent as well as hardworking.

title: Conjunction 'Lest'
explanation: 'Lest' means 'otherwise' or 'to avoid'. It is followed by 'should' or the base verb (V1). (e.g., 'Work hard, lest you *should fail*').

examples.sentence: Work hard, lest you should fail.
Work hard, lest you will fail.

title: 'Until' vs. 'Unless'
explanation: 'Until' is time-oriented (refers to 'when'). 'Unless' is action-oriented and conditional (refers to 'if...not').

examples.sentence: Wait here until I come.
Wait here unless I come.

title: Error of Parallelism
explanation: Sentence elements that are alike in function must also be alike in grammatical form. (e.g., 'I like *singing*, *dancing*, and *walking*').

examples.sentence: He likes reading, writing, and playing.
He likes to read, writing, and playing.

title: Using Proper Prepositions
explanation: When using two words with different prepositional needs, state both prepositions. (e.g., 'He is superior *to* and older *than* me.').

examples.sentence: He is senior to and more experienced than me.
He is senior and more experienced than me.

title: 'Too much' vs. 'Much too'
explanation: Use 'too much' before a Noun (e.g., 'too much sugar'). Use 'much too' before an Adjective or Adverb (e.g., 'much too strong').

examples.sentence: He is much too clever for his age.
He is too much clever for his age.

title: Plural Nouns (e.g., 'belongings')
explanation: Words like 'belongings', 'earnings', 'surroundings', 'savings' function as plural nouns and take a plural verb.

examples.sentence: His belongings have been stolen.
His belongings has been stolen.

title: Usage of 'Politics'
explanation: Takes a singular verb when it's a subject ('Politics *is* a dirty game'). Takes a plural verb when it refers to a set of beliefs ('His politics *are*...').

examples.sentence: Politics is a dirty game.
Politics are a dirty game.

title: Usage of 'Mathematics' and 'Statistics'
explanation: Takes a singular verb when it's a subject. Takes a plural verb when 'Mathematics' means 'calculations' or 'Statistics' means 'data/facts'.

examples.sentence: Mathematics is an interesting subject.
Mathematics are an interesting subject.

title: 'A' vs 'The' with Possessives
explanation: 'A' means 'one of many' (e.g., 'A brother of mine' - I have multiple brothers). 'The' means 'only one' (e.g., 'The brother of me' - I have only one brother).

examples.sentence: A friend of mine is coming to meet me.
My one of the friends is coming to meet me.

title: 'too', 'as well', and 'also'
explanation: 'too' and 'as well' can be used at the end of a sentence. 'also' cannot; it is placed before the verb. ('I *also* went' or 'I went *too* / *as well*').

examples.sentence: I also went to the party.
I went to the party also.

title: Optative Sentences
explanation: Sentences expressing a wish, prayer, or curse ('May God bless you!', 'Long live the king!') use the base form of the verb (V1), regardless of the subject.

examples.sentence: May you live long!
May you lives long!

title: Pseudo Subjects (Dangling Participles)
explanation: Use 'It' as an introductory subject when a participle clause ('Being a rainy day...') does not logically modify the main subject ('I'). (e.g., '*It* being a rainy day, I did not go...').

examples.sentence: It being a rainy day, I could not go out.
Being a rainy day, I could not go out.

title: Infinitives describing Nouns
explanation: The infinitive must be followed by its required preposition. (e.g., 'I need a pen to write *with*,' 'This is a good bed to sleep *in*').

examples.sentence: This is a good book to read.
This is a good book to read in.

title: Using Two Different Helping Verbs
explanation: The main verb must be stated for both helping verbs if the form is different. (e.g., 'I have never *watched* and will never *watch* this movie.').

examples.sentence: I have never and will never cheat you.
I have never and will never cheated you.

title: Nouns that are always Plural
explanation: Words for tools or clothing with two parts ('scissors', 'pliers', 'tongs', 'jeans', 'trousers', 'shorts') and words like 'thanks', 'regards', 'premises', 'outskirts' are always plural.

examples.sentence: Where are my scissors?
Where is my scissors?

title: Nouns that appear Plural but are Singular
explanation: Words ending in '-ics' (Mathematics, Physics, Politics, Economics) and words like 'News', 'Innings', 'Summons' are singular and take a singular verb.

examples.sentence: The news is true.
The news are true.

title: Uncountable Nouns (No Plural Form)
explanation: Nouns like 'equipment', 'furniture', 'jewellery', 'luggage', 'machinery', 'poetry', 'scenery', 'information', 'advice', 'baggage', 'hair' are uncountable and do not have a plural form.

examples.sentence: The scenery of Kashmir is beautiful.
The sceneries of Kashmir are beautiful.

title: Conditional Sentences (Review)
explanation: A review of the three conditional types. Also notes that 'As soon as' and 'When' function like 'If' in Type 1 conditionals.

examples.sentence: If I had seen him, I would have stopped my car.
If I would have seen him, I would have stopped my car.

title: Possessive Adjectives with 'all' and 'both'
explanation: The possessive adjective (my, your, his) comes *after* 'all' or 'both'. (e.g., 'All my students,' not 'My all students'; 'Both my friends,' not 'My both friends').

examples.sentence: All my friends are here.
My all friends are here.

title: Superfluous Sentences (Conjunctions)
explanation: 'As soon as' is not followed by 'than'. 'As' (for reason) is not followed by 'so'. 'Due to' and 'the reason' are not used together.

examples.sentence: As soon as I reached the station, the train departed.
As soon as I reached the station, than the train departed.

title: Usage with 'Quantity'
explanation: Use the adjective 'small' with 'quantity', not 'little' or 'few'. (e.g., 'a *small* quantity of food').

examples.sentence: A small quantity of food was wasted.
A little quantity of food was wasted.

title: Confusing Verb Forms
explanation: Fly, Flew, Flown (air). Flow, Flowed, Flowed (water). Find, Found, Found (discover). Found, Founded, Founded (establish). Hang, Hanged, Hanged (person). Hang, Hung, Hung (thing).

examples.sentence: The river has overflowed its banks.
The river has overflown its banks.

title: Confusing Verb 'Lie'
explanation: Lie, Lied, Lied (to tell an untruth). Lay, Laid, Laid (to put something down). Lie, Lay, Lain (to recline or rest).

examples.sentence: He laid the book on the table.
He lay the book on the table.

title: Preposition with 'Die'
explanation: 'Die *of*' a direct cause, usually a disease (e.g., 'die of cancer'). 'Die *from*' an external or indirect cause (e.g., 'die from overwork', 'die from wounds').

examples.sentence: He died of cancer.
He died from cancer.

title: 'Beside' vs. 'Besides'
explanation: 'Beside' (preposition) = next to. 'Besides' (adverb or preposition) = in addition to, also.

examples.sentence: Besides a car, he has a bike.
Beside a car, he has a bike.

title: Adjectives ending in '-ly'
explanation: Words like 'friendly', 'miserly', 'cowardly', 'manly', 'weekly' are adjectives, not adverbs. To use as an adverb, say 'in a friendly manner'.

examples.sentence: He behaved in a friendly manner.
He behaved friendly.

title: Position of Adverbs
explanation: An adverb can *never* be placed between the main verb and its direct object. (e.g., 'He *often comes* to my house' or 'He *comes* to my house *often*').

examples.sentence: He often comes to my house.
He comes often to my house.

title: Order of Multiple Adverbs
explanation: The correct order is Adverb of Manner -> Adverb of Place -> Adverb of Time (MPT). (e.g., 'She sang *beautifully* (M) *at the concert* (P) *last night* (T).').

examples.sentence: He sang beautifully at the concert last night.
He sang at the concert beautifully last night.

title: 'Very' vs. 'Much'
explanation: 'Very' modifies positive degree adjectives and adverbs. 'Much' modifies comparative degree adjectives (much weaker) and past participles (much interested).

examples.sentence: I am very interested in this book.
I am much interested in this book.

title: 'Between...and' / 'From...to'
explanation: The correct pair is 'Between...and' (e.g., 'between 4 pm *and* 5 pm'). The other correct pair is 'From...to' (e.g., 'from 4 pm *to* 5 pm').

examples.sentence: He works from 9 am to 5 pm.
He works from 9 am and 5 pm.

title: Nouns with Different Plural Meanings
explanation: Some uncountable nouns have a different meaning when 's' is added. (e.g., 'Wood' (timber) vs. 'Woods' (forest); 'Air' (gas) vs. 'Airs' (arrogance); 'Advice' (counsel) vs. 'Advices' (information)).

examples.sentence: He gave me a piece of advice.
He gave me some advices.

title: Common Slang/Incorrect Phrasing
explanation: Avoid: 'English teacher' (use 'teacher of English'), 'family members' (use 'members of the family'), 'cousin brother/sister' (use 'cousin').

examples.sentence: He is a teacher of English.
He is an English teacher.

title: Possessive Adjectives for 'One' and 'Everyone'
explanation: The possessive for 'One' is 'one's' (e.g., 'One should do *one's* duty'). The possessive for 'Everyone' or 'Each' is 'his' (or 'her' if specified).

examples.sentence: One should do one's duty.
One should do his duty.

title: 'Fewer' vs. 'Less'
explanation: 'Fewer' is used for countable nouns (e.g., 'fewer students'). 'Less' is used for uncountable nouns (e.g., 'less water').

examples.sentence: There are fewer students in the class today.
There are less students in the class today.

title: 'Elder' vs. 'Older'
explanation: 'Elder' is used for family members (blood relations). 'Older' is used for people or things in general. Also covers 'Later' (time) vs 'Latter' (position) and 'Farther' (distance) vs 'Further' (additional).

examples.sentence: He is my elder brother.
He is my older brother.

title: Making Logical Comparisons
explanation: Ensure you compare like with like. (e.g., 'The *weather* of Delhi is better than *that of* Mumbai.'). Use 'that of' for singular, 'those of' for plural.

examples.sentence: The climate of Delhi is better than that of Mumbai.
The climate of Delhi is better than Mumbai.

title: Phrases Followed by Plural Nouns
explanation: Phrases 'One of the', 'either of', 'neither of', and 'each of' are always followed by a plural noun (but take a singular verb).

examples.sentence: One of my friends is a doctor.
One of my friend is a doctor.

title: Pronoun Case after Prepositions (Review)
explanation: (Repeat of Rule 41) Prepositions like 'but', 'except', 'between' must be followed by the objective case (me, him, her).

examples.sentence: Everyone but him was present.
Everyone but he was present.

title: Pronoun Case with Pseudo Subjects
explanation: The pronoun following 'It is...' must be in the subjective case. (e.g., 'It is *he* who should be blamed,' not 'It is him...').

examples.sentence: It is I who am to blame.
It is me who am to blame.

title: Correlative Words
explanation: The correct pairs are: 'Such...as', 'Else...but', 'Other/Otherwise...than'.

examples.sentence: He has no other option but to resign.
He has no other option than to resign.

title: Possessive of Plural Nouns ending in 's'
explanation: To avoid hissing sounds, a plural noun ending in 's' takes only an apostrophe (') for possession. (e.g., 'girls' school,' 'Pythagoras' theorem').

examples.sentence: This is a girls' school.
This is a girls's school.

title: Apostrophe with Possessive Pronouns
explanation: Never use an apostrophe with possessive pronouns. 'yours', 'ours', 'hers', 'theirs', 'its' are all correct as written.

examples.sentence: The dog wagged its tail.
The dog wagged it's tail.

title: Predicative Adjectives
explanation: Adjectives like 'afraid', 'asleep', 'aware', 'alone', 'ill', 'glad' come after a verb ('He is afraid'), not before a noun ('The afraid man' is incorrect).

examples.sentence: The child is asleep.
The asleep child is crying.
